abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Protected Areas
            Management Project (PGAP) for Morocco were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to global
            environment outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also moderately unsatisfactory.  The main lesson to be
            learned from the PGAP experience concerns the critical
            importance of formulating early on a fully functional
            financial system to ensure the efficient implementation of
            all the project activities. The failure of the Autonomous
            Administrative Unit for Forestry Products Development
            (SEGMA) account to deliver an effective and decentralized
            mechanism has hampered the entire PGAP operation. It may
            have appeared on paper to be the most suitable financial
            vehicle, but when changes occurred to the terms of its use
            and the host ministry was reorganized (into a high
            commission) there should have been a more concerted effort
            on both sides of the project to seek a more suitable
            alternative. This issue will be critical to the success of
            any future operation - and fortunately the new protected
            areas law should now provide the means to develop fully
            decentralized budgeting and management functions. The second
            important lesson learned is the necessity to formulate a
            realistic project design, grounded in practical and
            achievable activities with solid and measurable outputs.
            Otherwise, there is a risk that operations will become too
            dispersed and disconnected to achieve any lasting impact or
            sustainability. Finally, decentralized multi-purpose
            projects, such as the PGAP, require close, constant and
            efficient supervision (both internal and external), so
            adequate staffing and budgets must be allocated to achieve
            this level of oversight and support.

10975080.trustfund:
TF023494-GEF - MOROCCO : PROTECTED AREAS
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT,TF028965-GEF - PDF B PROTECTED AREAS
            MANAGEMENT PROJECT
10975080.majtheme: Rural development,Environment and natural resource management,Social dev/gender/inclusion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Protected Areas Management Project
            aims to improve conservation of globally significant
            ecosystems and species in Morocco; contribute to the
            establishment of a system of protected areas; and strengthen
            the institutional capacity for sustainable conservation
            management. There are four principal project components: 1)
            National capacity building will strengthen the institutional
            capacity of the Ministry of Water and Forestry and other
            main actors, in particular research and training
            institutions, in sustainable management and conservation of
            protected areas in Morocco. 2) The national parks component
            will support activities to enhance natural resources through
            ecotourism development; rehabilitate the most threatened and
            biologically most interesting habitat and species; and
            develop and implement rural development plans compatible
            with conservation objectives with user communities. 3) The
            Sites of Ecological and Biological Interest-reserves
            component will support activities to strengthen ecosystem
            management, ecotourism, participatory rural development, and
            basic equipment. 4) Public awareness and education will
            support activities to inform the Moroccan public on
            biodiversity, sustainable development, and protection of
            wildlife and flora.
